1.54.text: Hi, so right now I am doing my second volunteer project

5.36.text: with Volunteer Southern Africa and this is the Cheetah

9.04.text: Project. So I am going to show you all the things that

11.40.text: we get up to and what we do on this project.

17.64.text: So the two main goal of the Living With Cheetah program

21.24.text: is to: 1) breeding Cheetah  to strengthen their gene

24.42.text: pool and 2) to raise them, teach them how to hunt

27.86.text: and release them back into the wild.

30.58.text: So the first thing we did was of course get to know the

34.24.text: cats. Now, not all the cats can be approached.

37.28.text: Several of the Cheetahs  born at the project have been

39.92.text: born wild and are still wild, but others have been

43.16.text: hand reared, which means they were raised by human

46.50.text: touch, so they can be handled, pet and essentially

51.24.text: tamed. When he gets up, he is done and we don't force

58.68.text: him to to. He get one interaction per day.

64.72.text: This is Kiara and her brother Kenya over there. And they are

68.24.text: 10 months old. And of this litter of 5, there are only

70.78.text: 2 that we hand reared. How this process works

73.80.text: is that these little guys are now learning to hunt

77.08.text: and when they are old enough and are hunting well

79.16.text: enough, we release them with the other siblings

81.20.text: and they will eventually teach these siblings how to hunt

85.28.text: Now, these hunting skills are very important because

88.88.text: the only way a cheetah can be successfully released

91.64.text: back into the wild is if it knows how to hunt. Now

94.98.text: this is a step-by-step process that varies with age.

100.42.text: First, we start off with boxes, then we move into running

107.68.text: After that, we introduce them to the open field to get

111.48.text: them starting to chase and run after live prey.

119.32.text: However, our attempt at catching aerial shots of

122.60.text: cheetah hunting didn't go quite as planned, since they

124.94.text: they ended up being more fascinated with the drone

152.40.text: So right now it is 6 in the morning and we are getting

158.12.text: ready to take the big cheetah out on a hunt, so they

161.40.text: are going to be hunting for their food here on the game

165.24.text: reserve. Wish them luck. Just a heads up, slight

171.90.text: GRAPHIC WARNING. We are going to drive them to a

175.02.text: point where we think there is enough antelope, offload

176.32.text: the cats and walk them to a point. Then we are going to

178.66.text: release the harnesses and we are going to stalk, go

183.08.text: down to the ground, because there is no use us having

186.52.text: our heads up while they are stalking and we are walking

188.24.text: like a bunch of turds. We are going to go down. We

189.92.text: don't want the antelope to see us. We will watch.

193.22.text: As soon as they take off, we chase on foot. We run.

210.66.text: A very successful kill. I tried to run as fast as I could

215.56.text: but apparently running with cheetahs is very difficult

221.10.text: It's a learning curve and in about years time they will

225.30.text: be ready to be put back in the wild. As long as they

228.50.text: know how to hunt, we have to release them.

229.00.text: When we are not teaching cheetah how to hunt , we are

231.78.text: working with them in other stimulating ways like walks

251.26.text: Seriously, does she know what she is doing?

258.48.text: Just taking cheetah for a walk. It's cool.

280.98.text: And not just the cheetah,  there are other adorable

284.46.text: animals at the project. So here is a sole survivor of a

288.14.text: fire. Her entire family was killed. They generally have

293.26.text: long tails, he lost his. Aside from that, he

296.70.text: is very awesome. He looks for eagles very often

299.26.text: So pretty much Zulu and the Banded Mongoose Lulu

304.68.text: She is an escape artist of note. Zulu. That one is Lulu

308.20.text: When someone else is holding him. He can get a bit

311.20.text: zealous. Right now you are his property.

327.18.text: So what we are about to do now is we are going to go

330.30.text: fetch Kira. She is our free run cheetah. The reason she

333.34.text: free runs is that she sadly can't be released.  Now she

336.86.text: can't be released is because when she was 4 days old

338.12.text: her mother accidentally stepped on her and broke

361.10.text: Another awesome part of Living with Cheetah project

364.62.text: is the game drives on their private reserve.

427.26.text: So, at the waterfall we stopped at for lunch on

431.58.text: our game drive. Look at it.

434.98.text: I think some people are going swimming.

438.20.text: Very possible. Not me though. I don't think that is

471.96.text: Thank you for watching. If you enjoyed Living with

475.32.text: Cheetah programs give it a thumbs up. And if you

478.20.text: want to see the other program I did. Living with Big Cats

486.74.text: And if you are not already, hit the subscribe button
